messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilderTest.testLang294()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
1732 :     public void testLang294() {
1733 :         StrBuilder sb = new StrBuilder("\n%BLAH%\nDo more stuff\neven more stuff\n%BLAH%\n");
1734 :         sb.deleteAll("\n%BLAH%"); // error occurred here
1736 :     }
```

The passing test with the highest token similarity to the failing test looks like:

 ```None
```

 Functions covered by passing tests are less likely to be buggy.
It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
	at java.lang.System.arraycopy(Native Method)
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.deleteImpl(StrBuilder.java:1114)
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.deleteAll(StrBuilder.java:1188)
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilderTest.testLang294(StrBuilderTest.java:1734)
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.
Classes covered by failing tests belong to the package `org.apache.commons.lang.text`. Next, I will retrieve the methods covered by failing tests for the `StrBuilder` class.

The failing test covers several methods in the `StrBuilder` class, including the method `deleteAll(String)`. The failure occurred in the `deleteAll` method, specifically at line 1734 in the test `testLang294`. 

Next, I will retrieve the code snippet for the `deleteAll` method in the `StrBuilder` class to understand its implementation better.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The `deleteAll` method in the `StrBuilder` class takes a `String` parameter `str` and deletes all occurrences of that `String` within the `StrBuilder` object. It does so by iterating over the indexes where the `String` is found and deleting the corresponding substring.

The error occurred at line 1734 in the `testLang294` test, which calls the `deleteAll` method with a `String` parameter `"\n%BLAH%"`. The error suggests an `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException` in the `deleteAll` method. This exception typically occurs when the index being accessed by the method is out of bounds.

Based on the code snippet of the `deleteAll` method, it seems like the issue might be related to the calculation of indexes while deleting substrings. I will now suggest potential locations to be fixed.
The issue seems to be related to index calculation in the `deleteAll` method of the `StrBuilder` class. To fix the bug, the following method should be investigated:

```
org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.deleteAll(java.lang.String)
```

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
